author: By Ian Austen
title: Trudeau Rejects Retaliation as India Moves to Expel Canadian Diplomats
description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada said that his country is in talks with India to avert the expulsions.
content: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada said on Tuesday that his country was in talks with India over its latest demand that dozens of Canadian diplomats leave within a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey
title: Telling the Truth About Mexico, and Dying for It
description: Drug violence and government corruption have put the country’s journalists in peril. In one town, reporters tried to fight back.
content: On Oct. 19, 2021, Armando Linares López was writing up notes from an interview when his cellphone buzzed with an unknown number. Linares, 49 and stocky with black hair that was just starting to show gray streaks, ran an online news site in a small Mexican city called Zitácuaro; he knew his beat so intimately that calls from unfamiliar phone numbers were rare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Here Are the Finalists for the 2023 National Book Awards
description: Nana Kwame Adjei-Brenyah, Paul Harding and Cristina Rivera Garza are among the honorees. Winners will be announced next month.
content: A dystopian novel about a private, for-profit prison system in which inmates compete for their freedom in death matches that are broadcast live. A history of Native American people and the development of American democracy. And a graphic novel about a Muslim family’s road trip to Disney World.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Justices Return
description: Business regulation is the big story of the new Supreme Court term.
content: With the Supreme Court’s new term having started this week, I want to use today’s newsletter to give you context on the issue that Adam Liptak — who covers the court for The Times — calls “the story of the term”: business regulation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: McCarthy Is Ousted as Speaker, Leaving the House in Chaos
description: A handful of far-right Republicans broke with their party and voted to remove Kevin McCarthy from his leadership post. He said he would not run again.
content: The House voted on Tuesday to oust Representative Kevin McCarthy from the speakership, a move without precedent that left the chamber without a leader and plunged it into chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: What to Know About Sam Bankman-Fried’s Fraud Trial
description: Mr. Bankman-Fried is accused of orchestrating a vast scheme to siphon billions of dollars of FTX customer money.
content: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the collapsed FTX cryptocurrency exchange, is set to stand trial, after a yearlong corporate saga that has made headlines around the world and devastated the digital asset industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: Colleges Snap Up Unused Office Space in a Slumping Market
description: As companies with hybrid work forces reduce square footage, universities see an opportunity to buy buildings at bargain prices.
content: When Jack Welch, the longtime chief executive of General Electric, presided over a global headquarters on a sylvan expanse in Fairfield, Conn., in the 1980s and ‘90s, he probably did not envision college students streaming into its two pristine office buildings. But on a recent morning, students at Sacred Heart University headed to classrooms on floors once filled with file cabinets and cubicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Americans Deserve Better From the House of Representatives
description: A tiny faction of Republican extremists are again putting their interests over the business of running the government.
content: This article has been updated to include new information about Mr. McCarthy’s decision not to run for speaker again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Alexander McQueen Names a New Top Designer
description: Sean McGirr, an Irish designer, was announced as the British label’s next creative director days after Sarah Burton showed her final collection for the brand.
content: Three days after Sarah Burton showed her final Alexander McQueen collection at Paris Fashion Week, the brand’s parent company named Sean McGirr, an Irish designer, as her successor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Baked Tilapia, Simply Seasoned With Lemon and Pepper
description: Because “basic” isn’t always a bad word.
content: You need recipe basics the same way you need wardrobe basics: the pair of jeans or white shirt that you can easily throw on, items that mix and match with other things or stand alone. The baked fish below from Ali Slagle is just that, a streamlined dish that’s simple to make and goes with just about any seasoning or side. (The other four recipes are just downright delicious.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: John Kelly, a Former White House Chief of Staff, Confirms Trump’s Disparaging of Veterans
description: In a statement to CNN, Mr. Kelly corroborated reporting from 2020 that he declined to confirm at the time despite pressure from friends and associates to do so.
content: John F. Kelly, the onetime chief of staff to former President Donald J. Trump, confirmed on Monday some of Mr. Trump’s most startling comments about service members and veterans, reeling them off in a statement in which he said his onetime boss had “contempt for our democratic institutions, our Constitution and the rule of law.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Shows Return After Five Months Off the Air
description: “We’ve been gone so long, ‘The Bachelor’ is now a grandfather,” Jimmy Kimmel joked on Monday.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harriet Lane
title: Conjuring Mary Shelley’s Outrageous Imagination
description: A Dutch novelist envisions the creation of “Frankenstein,” Shelley’s most famous work.
content: The circumstances leading up to the writing of “Frankenstein,” the creative act at the heart of Anne Eekhout’s new novel — first published in the Netherlands in 2021, now translated into English — are every bit as wild and unlikely as the tale of the creature itself. It’s 1816, and 18-year-old Mary Godwin, the daughter of the radical philosophers Mary Wollstonecraft and William Godwin, is summering scandalously on the shores of Lake Geneva with her married lover, the firebrand poet and free-love advocate Percy Shelley; their baby son; and her high-strung stepsister Claire Claremont. (Mary becomes Mary Shelley later that year, following the suicide of Percy’s first wife, barely mentioned in Eekhout’s novel.) Their neighbors in Cologny are Lord Byron (“Albe,” after his initials) and his physician, John Polidori.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Creating ‘Fair and Appropriate Testing’
description: Responses to a guest essay by Adam Grant. Also: The truth about apologies; Joe Biden’s hubris; TV and the boomers.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor and Catie Edmondson
title: Who Is Patrick McHenry, the Interim House Speaker?
description: The Republican from North Carolina and an
content: With the House leaderless after a right-wing faction ousted Kevin McCarthy from the speakership on Tuesday, Representative Patrick McHenry of North Carolina will temporarily take up the gavel as interim speaker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: 2 U.S. Soldiers Are Dead in Alaska After Vehicle Flips in Training Area
description: An Army tactical vehicle overturned after its driver lost control on a dirt road near Salcha, Alaska.
content: Two U.S. Army soldiers died and 12 others were injured on Monday after a military vehicle flipped en route to a training exercise in Alaska, the U.S. Army Alaska said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Memories of a Soldier from Chinatown, by 12 Speakers
description: Danny Chen, who died by suicide after being subjected to hazing in Afghanistan, will be memorialized by readers, including a well-known playwright.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll find out about a commemoration for a soldier from Chinatown who died by suicide after being subjected to hazing by other soldiers in Afghanistan. We’ll also see how the first day of Donald Trump’s civil trial unfolded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: What Misconceptions Do People Have About Where You Live?
description: What is the reputation of your town or city? How much of it is accurate, in your opinion?
content: When you tell people where you’re from, how do they react? Do you think their view of the place is accurate? Or do they have it all wrong?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Republican Voters Have Shown an Appetite for Candidates’ Calls to Use Military Force Against Mexican Cartels
description: G.O.P. candidates on the trail have used the idea as both an effective applause line and a solution for what many Republicans see as an unchecked border.
content: Iowa is more than 1,000 miles from the U.S. border with Mexico. But Republican primary voters in the Midwestern state have embraced what has become almost orthodoxy among the G.O.P. candidates vying for their votes: deploying military forces to fight drug cartels and secure the border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: The climate crisis is also a health crisis
description: Rising global temperatures are undoing hard-earned progress.
content: Humankind has never been better at fighting diseases. Researchers are coming up with new vaccines and treatments at an astounding speed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Produce Takes Center Stage at Jean’s
description: Max Chodorow and Ashwin Deshmukh collaborate on a new restaurant near the Public Theater, Junoon brings Indian hawker street food to the East Village at Jazba and more restaurant news.
content: An American bistro with its eye on New York is what Max Chodorow, a son of the prolific restaurateur Jeffrey Chodorow, intends for this restaurant just steps from the Public Theater. At one time, the space housed the elder Mr. Chodorow’s Asia de Cuba and Butter. Now, his son has a teamed up with Ashwin Deshmukh, a managing partner at Superiority Burger, for this new venture. The restaurant is distinguished by using produce from Max Chodorow’s farm in New Hope, Pa. In addition, meat, poultry and some of the seafood also come from local sources. His menu offers grilled oysters with Espelette hollandaise, lobster rolls served with a shot of lobster bisque, a French dip sandwich, mussel bouillabaisse, wood-grilled half chicken, seared local fluke meunière, bone-in tuna au poivre and an espresso crème brûlée. Pedro Cruz runs the kitchen. The titular Jean is no one in particular: It was chosen as a name that works both in English and French. Mirrors, gold leaf, Venetian plaster and an open kitchen define this informal room that seats 110. (Opens Friday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amal El-Mohtar
title: A Novel Imagines the Volatile Life of a 7th-Century Saint
description: “Menewood” continues Nicola Griffith’s epic portrayal of the abbess Hild of Whitby.
content: In 2013, Nicola Griffith published “Hild,” a novel exploring the early life of St. Hild of Whitby (614-80). It was a masterpiece of immersion, building its seventh-century setting stitch by stitch through Griffith’s close scrutiny of work and weather, language and literature, women and war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Wildfire Smoke From Canada Creates Unhealthy Air Quality in Florida
description: Moderate to unhealthy air quality was being reported across the state on Tuesday as smoke filtered down to the surface.
content: What would normally have been a pleasant sea breeze along the eastern coast of Florida was instead a hazy plume of smoke on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Iran’s Captive Minds
description: A blockbuster story about Tehran’s influence peddling shows the peril of seeking access with despots.
content: In June 2014, Dina Esfandiary and Ariane Tabatabai wrote an article in The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, making the case that Iran had “genuine and reasonable concerns” about its nuclear fuel supplies and that it would need many more centrifuges to become energy independent. There had to be “a mechanism to guarantee Iranian supply,” they wrote, a position plainly sympathetic to Tehran’s interests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: Ex-Detroit Police Chief, a Republican, Enters Michigan Senate Race
description: James Craig, who ran for governor last year but was disqualified, will compete against former Representative Mike Rogers in the Republican primary race for an open Senate seat.
content: James Craig, a former Detroit police chief, announced on Tuesday that he was running for the Senate seat in Michigan being vacated by Debbie Stabenow, a Democrat who is retiring after more than two decades in the position.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Who Knew Recycling Could Be So Dramatic?
description: At Maison Margiela, John Galliano tells an epic tale in clothes.
content: These days, narrative theater — the kind that involves characters and stories and spinning out entire fantasy scenarios that require costumes — has largely fallen out of fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Cutler, Steve Eder and Robert Gebeloff
title: Jailed by the Thousands, Without Charges, to Act as Witnesses
description: The Justice Department has invoked a 200-year-old law to detain thousands of undocumented immigrants as witnesses in smuggling cases. Judges have locked up some for six months or more.
content: Several months ago, as a federal judge worked through a docket of smuggling cases in the bustling border city of Laredo, Texas, three people were escorted into the courtroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Skeptical in That Could Hobble Consumer Watchdog
description: The justices heard a challenge to the way Congress funded the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau but seemed persuaded that it was constitutional.
content: A majority of the justices at a Supreme Court argument on Tuesday seemed ready to reject a challenge to the constitutionality of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, the agency set up during the Obama administration to crack down on abuses by banks and other financial services providers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Central Park’s Great Lawn Is Closed Until April After Concert Damage
description: The Global Citizen Festival drew around 30,000 concertgoers to the rain-drenched park, causing extensive damage to one of its most famous areas, officials said.
content: The Great Lawn, the 12-acre oval of green space that is one of the most popular gathering places in Central Park, will be closed to the public until April after it was damaged during a concert late last month, the Central Park Conservancy confirmed on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Gaetz’s Ouster of McCarthy Draws Attention to His Ethics Issues
description: Representative Matt Gaetz is facing a House Committee inquiry into allegations of sexual misconduct and misuse of funds. Representative Kevin McCarthy has argued Mr. Gaetz’s move against his speakership is payback.
content: Representative Matt Gaetz’s successful push to oust Speaker Kevin McCarthy has cemented his status as one of the most reviled members of the House of Representatives — including among many of his fellow Republicans — and drawn attention to a long-running investigation by the House Ethics Committee into Mr. Gaetz’s conduct.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Hiba Yazbek and Gabby Sobelman
title: Israeli Herders Spread Across West Bank, Displacing Palestinians
description: Palestinian herding communities are abandoning their villages, ceding huge swaths of land to nearby Israeli settlers. Settler activists say it’s the result of their new strategy in the West Bank.
content: In the abandoned sheep pens of Al Baqa, a remote Palestinian hamlet in the West Bank, you can still smell the livestock. But the sheep themselves, as well as their shepherds, have vanished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Countries of Africa Look Ahead With Hope
description: Despite its problems, the continent is showing positive signs for democracy. Will that lead to a new future for its 1.2 billion citizens?
content: Moderator: Steven Erlanger, chief diplomatic correspondent, Europe, The New York Times
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: At 104, She Wondered: Could She Skydive Again?
description: This spring, Dorothy Hoffner said, she had a sudden yearning to fall from 10,000 feet for a second time.
content: Dorothy Hoffner, born in 1918, had survived both the Spanish flu and Covid pandemics, as well as her first skydiving attempt at age 100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleanore Park, Brian Gallagher and Tejal Rao
title: The 25 Best Restaurants in San Francisco Right Now
description: From world-class Korean barbecue to Mission-style burritos to quintessential California cuisine, here are our current favorites.
content: In the Where to Eat: 25 Best series, we’re highlighting our favorite restaurants in cities across the United States. These lists will be updated as restaurants close and open, and as we find new gems to recommend. As always, we pay for all of our meals and don’t accept free items.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley
title: In Shipping, a Push to Slash Emissions by Harnessing the Wind
description: More ships are running on wind power, as the global industry tries to fight climate change. One concept has backing from Abba, the Swedish pop stars.
content: One ship was pulled across the sea with the help of an enormous sail that looked as if it belonged to a kite-surfing giant. Another navigated the oceans between China and Brazil this summer with steel and composite-glass sails as high as three telephone poles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Hollywood Actors and Studios, Resuming Talks, Plan to Meet Again Wednesday
description: The session on Monday was the first in more than two months and included top industry executives.
content: Negotiations between striking Hollywood actors and entertainment companies ended on Monday with the sides jointly announcing a return to talks on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: For This ‘Jeopardy!’ Champ, Winning Came Before the Buzzer
description: Amy Schneider’s new memoir, “In the Form of a Question,” captures a life of bold choices well beyond wagers on the Daily Double.
content: Amy Schneider is one of the “Jeopardy!” greats, second only to Ken Jennings in games won (40 to Jennings’s 74). She’s fourth overall in regular-season winnings ($1,382,800) and fifth if you include tournaments ($1,632,800). In her new memoir, “In the Form of a Question,” she locks down a No. 1 spot, though, for best hang. Extolling the virtues of recreational drugs, the thrills of casual sex, the flirting potential in offering tarot readings? Ken Jennings could never.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval and Campbell Robertson
title: Congressman Becomes Latest Carjacking Victim as D.C. Crime Continues to Rise
description: The police recovered Representative Henry Cuellar’s vehicle after he was carjacked in the Navy Yard neighborhood. He was unharmed.
content: Since the start of the year, hundreds of drivers across the nation’s capital have been robbed of their vehicles at gunpoint. On Monday night, the latest victim was a member of Congress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy and Andy Newman
title: Judge Let Abusive Parents Keep Daughter. Days Later, She Was Dead.
description: A Brooklyn judge ordered Ella Vitalis, 1, who died of blunt force trauma, to stay with her parents, after the child welfare agency argued she should be removed.
content: A judge in Brooklyn overruled city concerns that a baby was being abused and allowed her to return to her parents’ care the day before she was fatally injured, according to court papers obtained by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: A New Way to Prevent S.T.I.s: A Pill After Sex
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention plans to recommend a widely used antibiotic, though not for everyone just yet.
content: In a bid to stem the resurgence of sexually transmitted infections, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention plans to recommend doxycycline, a widely used antibiotic, for use after an unprotected sexual encounter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: A Plot to Oust the House Speaker Hits Weary Investors
description: Matt Gaetz’s move to unseat Kevin McCarthy is adding volatility to equity and bond markets.
content: Representative Matt Gaetz of Florida moved on Monday to oust Kevin McCarthy as speaker, looking to exact punishment on the top House Republican for siding with Democrats to forge a short-term deal to avert a government shutdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Zach Montague
title: Hunter Biden Pleads Not Guilty to Federal Gun Charges
description: The president’s son was arraigned on charges of lying about his drug use on a form he filled out to purchase a handgun in 2018.
content: Hunter Biden, the president’s son, pleaded not guilty in federal court on Tuesday to charges stemming from his purchase of a handgun in 2018, the latest development in an investigation that Republicans have tried to use to inflict political damage on his father.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: U.S. and World Leaders Pledge Support for Ukraine ‘for as Long as It Takes’
description: President Biden, in a conference call with world leaders amid tumult in Congress, insisted that U.S. aid would not be interrupted.
content: President Biden has told his counterparts in a number of allied countries that he remains confident that Congress will approve military and humanitarian assistance for Ukraine “for as long as it takes” in spite of opposition among some Republicans that blocked funding over the weekend, a national security spokesman said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justine Martin
title: ‘We Can’t Be Together Forever.’ But We Can Try.
description: At the dawn of their teenage years, the bond between the twins Raphaël and Rémi begins to weaken. But during the summer, time seems to stand still.
content: When I was younger, I used to babysit the twin brothers Raphaël and Rémi. They were inseparable best friends, but as the years passed I noticed that a distance was slowly starting to form between them. As they entered their teenage years, Rémi was feeling guilty about growing up “faster” than his brother, who has developmental disabilities. Raphaël struggled to follow Rémi and adapt to this new reality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli, Suhasini Raj and Hari Kumar
title: New Delhi Police Raid Homes and Offices of Journalists
description: The sweep caught up the founder and contributors of a left-leaning news website, according to other news outlets and those raided. A Times investigation had linked the site to a pro-China network.
content: The police in New Delhi raided the homes and offices on Tuesday of journalists who worked as staff or contributors for a left-leaning online news portal known for criticisms of the Indian government. The founder and editor of the news site and one of its journalists were also arrested, according to The Indian Express, a local outlet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Here’s What Happens Now That Gaetz Has Moved to Oust McCarthy
description: The resolution that Representative Matt Gaetz put forward on Monday gives Speaker Kevin McCarthy two legislative days to call a vote on whether he should keep his post. Action could come as early as Tuesday.
content: Representative Matt Gaetz pressed forward on Monday evening to force a vote on removing Speaker Kevin McCarthy from his post, setting the stage for a dramatic showdown this week between Mr. McCarthy and his far-right critics.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Global Shippers Again Embrace the ‘Free Fuel’
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, October 4, 2023.
content: “We want to decarbonize — why not use what’s available? Wind is free fuel.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: How Four Leaders Are Turning the World Upside Down
description: That was not the plan.
content: Ever since learning that in 1947, Walter Lippmann popularized the term “Cold War” to define the emerging conflict between the Soviet Union and the United States, I thought it would be cool to be able to name a historical epoch. Now that the post-Cold War has expired, the post-post-Cold War that we’ve entered is just begging to be named. So here goes: It’s the age of “That Was Not the Plan.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: There Is No Clear Replacement Candidate for McCarthy
description: Republicans focused on ousting Speaker Kevin McCarthy aren’t in agreement about who they want to replace him.
content: If not Speaker Kevin McCarthy, then who?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Piecing Together What Remained, So Mothers Could Bury Their Sons
description: A Times reporter hiked to a rugged region in Greece where the bodies of 18 asylum seekers were found. She returned, weeks later, with a man who had lost his brother.
content: On Aug. 23, I stood inside what was left of a burned shack on a hillside. The air was heavy with smoke, but after hours of reporting I had given up covering my mouth and nose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Barcelona’s Unfinished Masterpiece Is Now a Little More Finished
description: After 140 years, Antoni Gaudí’s unrealized masterpiece is finally nearing completion. But hurdles still remain, with construction to last until at least 2026.
content: More than 140 years after a Spanish bishop laid the cornerstone of Barcelona’s Sagrada Familia basilica, the famously incomplete church is inching toward the finish line, with five of its six central towers now finally fully built as of last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson and Emily Baumgaertner
title: Kaiser Permanente Workers Poised to Strike
description: The health care system provides care for 13 million people in eight states. Union officials say the job action — threatened for Wednesday — could be the largest strike by health care workers in recent U.S. history.
content: More than 75,000 Kaiser Permanente employees are threatening to walk out Wednesday morning if they cannot agree to a new labor contract. The previous contract expired on Saturday. Union leaders say this could be the largest strike by health care workers in recent U.S. history.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 4, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Oct. 4, 2023.
content: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about tension surrounding hunting rules in New Zealand referred incorrectly to New Zealand’s native mammals. Bats are a mammal native to New Zealand; it is not the case that New Zealand has no native land mammals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Trump Campaign Calls on Republicans to Cancel All Future Debates
description: Two top advisers to former President Donald J. Trump claimed without evidence that Democrats are working to “steal” the 2024 election.
content: As legal cases against former President Donald J. Trump churn forward on at least five fronts, two of them related to his lie that the 2020 election was stolen from him, his campaign is advancing baseless claims that the 2024 election, too, is on track to be stolen from him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Inside New York’s Least Competitive Bowling League
description: It started with a small group of friends. They invited their friends. Now, 100 or so players, many of whom work in fashion and design, meet for games that are in turn casual and chaotic.
content: The noise of the onlookers rose to a crescendo of screams as the ball hurtled toward the pins: Strike! A triumphant player spun around, grinning at the crowd. She and more than 50 others had come on a recent Sunday afternoon to the Manhattan location of the Gutter, a dimly lit venue on the Lower East Side, to participate in an amateur bowling league that’s organized every two weeks through a 100-person Instagram group chat named “Bowling Is Divine.” Dressed in vintage T-shirts, tank tops, baggy cargo pants and wide-legged jeans with an early 2000s feel, the group of 20- and 30-somethings — many of whom work in art, fashion and design — sipped on beers and lounged on leather couches while taking turns at the eight lanes they’d reserved.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: Harvey Awards to Induct 6 New Hall of Fame Members
description: The inductees will be honored at New York Comic Con on Oct. 13. Five are from the world of superheroes, and one is a pioneer of underground comics.
content: The Harvey Awards, which celebrates comic books, will be adding six members to its hall of fame. They will be inducted at New York Comic Con on Oct. 13.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Christensen
title: Viet Thanh Nguyen: Spy, Sympathizer, Son
description: The author blends polemic and family history in a fragmentary memoir, “A Man of Two Faces.”
content: “I am a spy, a sleeper, a spook, a man of two faces,” Viet Thanh Nguyen’s 2015 debut novel, “The Sympathizer,” begins. The unnamed narrator is a biracial, American-educated communist informant in the employ of a South Vietnamese general in the waning days of war. His twin faces — North and South, East and West, communist and nationalist, white and not — grant him the titular sympathy that is both a blessing and a curse. A “man of two minds,” he commiserates with his foes as easily as he deceives his friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mathew Silver and Vjosa Isai
title: Visit to Fashion Mogul’s Office Ended in Rape, Woman Testifies
description: The woman told a Toronto jury that Peter Nygard sexually assaulted her when she was 28, and she was the first of five accusers to appear in court in what is expected to be a seven-week trial.
content: Hours after a Rolling Stones concert in downtown Toronto, a woman found herself trapped in the plush bedroom of an office building with Peter Nygard, a renowned Canadian fashion mogul at the time, the woman testified in court on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: How to Become a Cricket Expert Just in Time for the Cricket World Cup
description: A game that is somewhat impenetrable to outsiders can, on occasion, reveal its joys to all.
content: Every four years, the world’s top cricket teams come together to determine which of them is the best of all at the Cricket World Cup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Russian Troops Cede Ground and Strike Back, Frustrating Ukraine’s Counteroffensive
description: Military analysts say that Russian commanders have been using a tactic known as “elastic defense” to prevent Ukraine from holding villages and other positions as staging grounds for future attacks.
content: Across desolate fields and shattered villages, Ukraine’s counteroffensive is confronting Russian minefields and Russian soldiers dug into elaborate trench networks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: DirecTV Says CNN Streaming Service Risks Violating Deal
description: The concern, raised in a letter, signals that cable and satellite providers may push back against streaming services full of shows they’re already paying for.
content: CNN’s plan to offer a streaming version of its popular lineup has hit some resistance less than a week after its debut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: If You’re Talking About His Hair, This N.B.A. Star Is Winning
description: Jimmy Butler’s emo persona was as short-lived as it was spectacular. Regardless of his motivation, it kept the Miami Heat’s media day decidedly off-topic.
content: Jimmy Butler, a forward for the Miami Heat, has never been concerned with what anyone expects of him. He blasts country music in the Heat’s locker room, irritating most of his N.B.A. teammates. He started his own pandemic-era coffee company, initially charging $20 a cup — for sizes small, medium and large. He also is a ferocious competitor, and he pledged on Monday that he would lead the Heat back to the N.B.A. finals this season.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 3, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Oct. 3, 2023.
content: An article on Sunday about Congress narrowly averting a government shutdown misstated Republicans’ status in the House. They hold a small majority, not a small minority.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter and Tripp Mickle
title: Spotify Gave Subscribers Music and Podcasts. Next: Audiobooks.
description: A year after adding à la carte sales of audiobooks, Spotify is offering paying subscribers 15 hours of books a month.
content: Four years ago, Spotify’s business was stagnating. Apple had overtaken it as the top paid music service in the United States, losses were mounting and customer growth was slowing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Anderson
title: Not Everyone Thinks the Middle East Can Have Democracy
description: Vincent Bevins’s “If We Burn” and Robert D. Kaplan’s “The Loom of Time” consider protest movements of the past and the drive for democracy in countries like Egypt, Syria and Iraq.
content: In early November 1914, as the storm clouds of World War I closed in on the Middle East, the American consul general in Beirut sent an urgent message to the U.S. secretary of state. “Sir,” W. Stanley Hollis wrote, “I have the honor to report that conditions are going from bad to worse here.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Police Robot
description: New York City will deploy a “fully autonomous” security robot in one of its subway stations. Would you welcome one in your town or city?
content: It’s a bird. It’s a plane. No, it’s a crime-fighting robot!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Mike Isaac
title: Campbell Brown, Who Led Facebook News, Leaves Meta
description: Ms. Brown’s exit indicates how Meta’s priorities around news and its relationships with media companies have changed.
content: When Facebook was being battered in 2017 for distributing false and misleading news, the social network turned to Campbell Brown, a veteran journalist, to smooth over its relationships with the media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Case and Angus Deaton
title: Without a College Degree, Life in America Is Staggeringly Shorter
description: There are two Americas, and they are divided by a college degree.
content: By many measures, the U.S. economy is thriving: Unemployment stands close to the 50-year low set in April, the fraction of people age 25 to 54 in work is at a two-decade high, gross domestic product is growing rapidly, inflation is falling, and the S&P 500 is a third higher than it was before the Covid pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Will A.I. Transform the Economy, and if So, How?
description: Even a souped-up autocorrect can be pretty powerful.
content: So, will artificial intelligence transform the economy? Today I thought I’d take a break from my usual preoccupation with ongoing crises to engage in a bit of bigthink about how technology may change the economic landscape in the years ahead, including a topic that seems important but hasn’t drawn much attention: how A.I. might change the U.S. budget outlook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Your Guide to the New Right
description: From U.S. senators to the “lost boys,” the New Right is far from a monolith. Stephanie Slade breaks down how each faction departs from conventional conservatism.
content: The New Right has been associated with everyone from Senator Josh Hawley of Missouri to right-wing influencers and Catholic integralists. The breadth of the term can make it hard to define: Is the New Right a budding ideological movement or a toxic online subculture? What does it mean if it’s both?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: What Happened to Shen Beauty?
description: An airy boutique for salves and cosmetics was a Brooklyn hot spot for more than a decade. But many employees described an ugly workplace.
content: Shen Beauty was one of the most stylish shops in brownstone Brooklyn. Airy and bright, it offered an assortment of luxury beauty products and services like brow shaping, body waxes and facials. Despite its small size, it appeared regularly in Vogue, Vanity Fair, The New York Times and other publications. Its celebrity fans included Gwyneth Paltrow, who stopped in for a selfie, and Courteney Cox, who called it “the coolest store in Brooklyn.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Geoff Rickly
title: ‘Flora and Son’ and the Unspoken Truth About Songwriting
description: To one musician, John Carney’s films about budding artists mirror the joys and pitfalls of crafting tunes.
content: The revered record producer Rick Rubin once asked me if I was ready for a change. My band Thursday was coming off our third album, “War All the Time.” We had just cracked the Top 10 on the Billboard album chart by producing anthems for the very same post-hardcore genre that we had helped to shape, but Rubin was clear: The creative clock was already ticking. At a certain point, staying the same meant fading away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Water-Stressed Arizona Says State Will End Leases to Saudi-Owned Farm
description: The farm grows alfalfa for export to Saudi Arabia, where it’s fed to dairy cows. But the farm’s water use had come under scrutiny.
content: An Arizona farm owned by a Saudi Arabian company that grows alfalfa for export is set to lose its access to state land in a move Gov. Katie Hobbs said would “protect Arizona’s water future.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla and Heather Knight
title: California’s Newest Senator to Be Sworn In on Tuesday
description: Laphonza Butler, president of Emily’s List and a former labor leader, was named by Gov. Gavin Newsom to fill the seat left vacant by Dianne Feinstein’s death.
content: Less than five days after the death of Dianne Feinstein, California’s newest U.S. senator is scheduled to be sworn in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: R.N.C. Thwarts Plans for Unofficial Ramaswamy-Christie Debate
description: The candidates criticized the committee for threatening to bar them from future debates if they took part in a face-off presented by Fox News.
content: The entrepreneur Vivek Ramaswamy and Chris Christie, the former New Jersey Governor, lashed out at the Republican National Committee on Tuesday after the organization effectively squashed plans for the two presidential candidates to face off in an unofficial debate tonight on Fox News.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What’s on Your Fall Playlist?
description: Tell us which songs deliver sonic coziness for you.
content: I’m on vacation this week, so I won’t be sending out any new playlists. But many of you have been emailing to ask how you can listen to previous Amplifier playlists, and I’m happy to announce that we finally have them archived and updated here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: Russian Ruble Briefly Weakens to 100 Against U.S. Dollar
description: The currency has been significantly weaker since the start of the year, in a sign of the financial volatility prompted by the war in Ukraine.
content: The Russian ruble briefly weakened to a symbolically important exchange rate of 100 to the dollar on Tuesday for the first time since mid-August, when worries about wartime shocks to the economy led the central bank to call an emergency meeting at which it sharply raised interest rates to 12 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Sculptures That Don’t Have to Add Up to Work Like Magic
description: For decades, the architect and restaurateur Hans Noë has been making geometric wooden objects that are almost impossible to categorize.
content: The wooden objects Hans Noë constructs — columns, walls and confounding clumps of simple but unusual geometric solids — aren’t exactly sculpture. They’re not quite high design, either, or children’s toys, or math problems, or architectural maquettes. But they could almost fit in any of these categories, evoking forebears and influences as various as Constantin Brancusi, Ludwig Mies van der Rohe and Friedrich Froebel. And at the National Museum of Mathematics right now, the writer Lawrence Weschler, a friend of Noë’s son Alva, has brought four dozen of them together in the exhibition “Hans Noë — Sculpture.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Hours Before the Vote, Democrats Decided Not to Help McCarthy
description: After the speaker publicly blamed the shutdown on House Democrats, minority leader Hakeem Jeffries advised his party to vote against him.
content: The leader of the House Democrats instructed his caucus to vote to remove Speaker Kevin McCarthy after a party meeting on Tuesday morning became a bitter venting session in which Democrats aired their disdain for the top Republican.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Sex vs. Skin
description: Sometimes, what you see can make you think. Games of peekaboo at Valentino and Sacai.
content: Over the weekend, as Paris Fashion Week entered its final days, a colleague on one of the rough wood benches that is today’s equivalent of the gold ballroom chairs of the past leaned over and huffed, “But where’s the politics? Does no one care about what’s happening to women around the world?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Finding the Ideal Apartment Was Easy. Making It Theirs Was Harder.
description: After the deal fell through, they couldn’t stop thinking about the apartment and those Manhattan views. Sometimes persistence pays off.
content: Some people spend years looking for the right home. For New Yorkers Dan Mazzarini and Andy Grover, it took about 10 minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Same-Sex Behavior Evolved in Many Mammals to Reduce Conflict, Study Suggests
description: But the researchers cautioned that the work could not shed much light on sexual orientation in humans.
content: In more than 1,500 animal species, from crickets and sea urchins to bottlenose dolphins and bonobos, scientists have observed sexual encounters between members of the same sex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Stevie Nicks Is Latest Celebrity to Be Immortalized as Barbie
description: The performer worked with Mattel to create a doll in her likeness, wearing an outfit inspired by the one she wore on the cover of Fleetwood Mac’s “Rumours.” She showed it off onstage at Madison Square Garden.
content: Midway through Stevie Nicks’s concert at Madison Square Garden on Sunday night, the musician told the audience that she had a “surprise,” prompting speculation among audience members about a potential unexpected guest: Could it be Lindsey Buckingham?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: ‘Elemental’ Morphs From Flop to Hit, Raising Questions Along the Way
description: The Pixar film struggled at the box office initially. It has now made $500 million, but not before prompting the studio to re-examine its release strategy.
content: The headlines were murderous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo
title: Kevin McCarthy Is Out as Speaker. What Happens Now?
description: McCarthy’s unprecedented removal hurls the House into a state of havoc, as Republicans scramble to determine their next steps.
content: The House voted on Tuesday to oust Kevin McCarthy, Republican of California, from the speakership, an unprecedented development that plunged the chamber into chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Will Reid, Rikki Novetsky, Michael Simon Johnson, Eric Krupke, Liz O. Baylen, Michael Benoist, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: Sam Bankman-Fried Goes on Trial
description: The FTX founder, once seen as crypto’s messiah, is accused of what prosecutors describe as the largest financial fraud in recent history.
content: Sam Bankman-Fried, the fallen golden boy of crypto, is going on trial for what prosecutors are calling the largest financial fraud in recent history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Police Chief Who Ordered Raid on Kansas Newspaper Resigns
description: Gideon Cody orchestrated the widely criticized raids on The Marion County Record and the home of its publisher.
content: The police chief of Marion, Kansas, who had ordered raids on the office of a local newspaper and the home of its publisher in August resigned on Monday, an official said, after facing mounting questions over his officers’ aggressive actions against the news organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jake Nevins
title: The Best Parts of Being a Football Fan Are Off the Field
description: The N.F.L. season began with dramatic injuries. Luckily, for the league, we fans focus our energy on so many things besides the actual gameplay.
content: They say it takes 10 years to become a real New Yorker, but Aaron Rodgers seemed to earn his bona fides in just one summer. In March, after solemn contemplation at what he called a “darkness retreat” in Oregon, the 39-year-old announced, with pomp befitting his superlative N.F.L. résumé, his intentions to continue his career with the New York Jets, a young and hungry team whose otherwise first-rate roster happened to be missing a serviceable quarterback. The move took Rodgers from the league’s smallest market, in Green Bay, to its largest, and he leveled up accordingly, refashioning himself as a city boy. He purchased a $9.5 million home in the New Jersey suburbs, naturally, but treated a young teammate to dinner at Carbone in Greenwich Village. He sat courtside at Knicks games, next to Jessica Alba, and shopped downtown at Rag & Bone. He went to MetLife Stadium for Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour and later visited the Gershwin Theater to see “Wicked.” And the Jets, newly hyped as Super Bowl contenders, were selected to be featured on the 18th season of the all-access series “Hard Knocks,” ensuring that HBO cameras would be on site to document the early days of his tenure in the Meadowlands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: United Airlines Will Buy 110 Planes From Airbus and Boeing
description: The airline, which is betting big on strong travel demand, said the new planes will expand its fleet and replace older planes.
content: United Airlines announced plans on Tuesday to buy 110 new airplanes, expanding its bet that the travel business would grow in the coming years even as evidence mounts that demand for flights is weakening right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Illinois Governor Tells Biden Migrant Influx Is ‘Untenable’
description: Gov. J.B. Pritzker of Illinois called for the president, a fellow Democrat, to step up federal aid as Chicago struggles to house thousands of migrants.
content: J.B. Pritzker, the influential Democratic governor of Illinois, called out President Biden on Monday for a federal response to the migrant crisis that he said was suffering from “red tape,” disorganization and a lack of funding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Trump Ordered Not to Comment on Judge’s Staff in Fraud Case
description: The former president attacked Justice Arthur F. Engoron’s clerk in a social media post that soon disappeared. He was called to account behind closed doors, then chastised in court as the judge issued a limited “gag order.”
content: The New York judge presiding over Donald J. Trump’s civil fraud trial ordered the former president Tuesday not to attack or even comment on court staff after Mr. Trump posted a message to social media targeting the judge’s law clerk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: Job Openings Rose in August, Shaking Markets
description: The report from the Labor Department is the latest reading on how the economy is withstanding the escalation of interest rates.
content: The number of job openings rose in August, the Labor Department reported on Tuesday, after three consecutive months of falling numbers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Here’s How Many Votes Kevin McCarthy Needs to Survive
description: The number will depend on how many House members show up to vote.
content: Kevin McCarthy’s fate could be determined by just a handful of votes. Precisely how many he needs to survive — or how many his opponents need to oust him — depends on how many House members show up to vote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler, Shane Goldmacher and Heather Knight
title: On Senate Choice, Newsom Was in a Box of His Own Making
description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California’s choice of a successor to Dianne Feinstein was complicated by two television interviews that attracted political pressure from many sides.
content: The question came from out of the blue in 2021, as Gov. Gavin Newsom of California was on television, fending off a campaign to recall him. If Senator Dianne Feinstein left office before the end of her term, Joy Reid of MSNBC wanted to know, would the governor rectify a glaring gap in representation and name a Black woman to fill the seat?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Ed Young Dies at 91; Infused His Illustrations With Chinese Tradition
description: Over a 60-year career, he illustrated some 100 books of fairy tales, poetry and memoirs, and won three Caldecott Medals.
content: Ed Young, whose illustrations in some 100 children’s books, many of which he also wrote, mesmerized young and not-so-young readers with intricate depictions of fairy tales, poetry and his own life story as a Chinese immigrant, died on Sept. 29 at his home in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: In Season 3 of ‘Only Murders,’ the Show, and the Deaths, Went On
description: Tuesday’s finale of “Only Murders in the Building” wrapped a season that was a love letter to Broadway musicals, not least because it was a little silly.
content: This notebook contains spoilers for the Season 3 finale of “Only Murders in the Building.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kalyn Wolfe, Patricia Mazzei and Colbi Edmonds
title: Matt Gaetz, a Polarizing Figure in Congress, Is Polarizing at Home, Too
description: In an overwhelmingly Republican district, Mr. Gaetz is admired for shaking up the House, but he also has plenty of critics.
content: He is polarizing in Washington and polarizing at home. And in both places these days, he is getting more attention than anyone might expect, given his lack of seniority and thin legislative record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Eric Adams Thinks His Critics Are Fools and Buffoons. Nothing Personal.
description: The mayor has lashed out at the many critiques of his administration, sometimes questioning whether they may be racially biased.
content: At a high school in Southeast Queens, not far from where he grew up, Mayor Eric Adams began addressing the crowd at a community conversation. Introductory pleasantries quickly yielded to complaints of indignities the mayor said he has suffered, and he began excoriating his critics, mostly unnamed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Takeaways From a New Book on Sam Bankman-Fried
description: “Going Infinite,” by Michael Lewis, offers a behind-the-scenes account of Mr. Bankman-Fried’s rise and fall.
content: On the same day that Sam Bankman-Fried’s trial on federal fraud charges begins, the best-selling author Michael Lewis is set to publish a widely anticipated book on Tuesday about Mr. Bankman-Fried’s failed cryptocurrency exchange, FTX.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Bus Drives Off Venice Overpass, Killing at Least 21
description: Italian officials said that the bus had been full of tourists, and that two minors were among the dead.
content: A bus filled with tourists in Venice careened through an overpass guardrail, crashed near train tracks and exploded on Tuesday evening, killing at least 21 people on board and wounding more than a dozen more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Ryn Jirenuwat
title: 14-Year-Old Fatally Shoots 2 at Mall in Bangkok, Officials Say
description: Thailand has one of the highest gun ownership and gun homicide rates in Southeast Asia, still the episode left the country reeling.
content: A 14-year-old with a gun opened fire in a luxury shopping mall in downtown Bangkok on Tuesday, the authorities said, killing two people and injuring five in one of Thailand’s most popular tourist destinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Wednesday Briefing: McCarthy Ousted as House Speaker
description: Plus wind-powered merchant ships to fight climate change.
content: Lawmakers in the U.S. House of Representatives voted yesterday to remove Speaker Kevin McCarthy from his leadership position. The vote was instigated by a group of hard-liners from his own Republican Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: Allegra Kent Conjures ‘Messages From the Air, the Atmosphere’
description: The iridescent Balanchine ballerina returns to New York City Ballet this season to coach for “La Sonnambula.” What does she want? Mystery.
content: It was the first ballet that made sense to her. There was mystery, passion, pain. The music, by Vittorio Rieti, after themes from Bellini operas, swept her into another world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper and Amelia Nierenberg
title: The Pizza Influencer With a Private Jet and a ‘Troll Army’
description: Dave Portnoy, the controversial founder of Barstool Sports, is now almost certainly America’s most influential person in pizza.
content: Tito Ibarra traveled from Clemson, S.C., to New York City with one mission: to eat a slice from all 35 pizzerias at the One Bite Pizza Festival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Conservative Catholics, Relegated to Sidelines, Denounce Papal Gathering
description: As bishops and laypeople from around the world prepared to gather at the Vatican, traditionalist Catholics who would not be among them staged their own show.
content: Sitting under the bright house lights of a theater near the Vatican, Cardinal Raymond Leo Burke, the de facto leader of the Roman Catholic Church’s opposition to Pope Francis, displayed a theatrical sense of timing on Tuesday for the adoring conservatives in the red velvet seats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By M. Anthony Mills
title: Why So Many Americans Are Losing Trust in Science
description: We may be entering a new political order polarized around institutional trust.
content: Dr. Mandy Cohen has been on a national tour. The new director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, she aims to rebuild trust in that troubled agency at a moment when Covid-19 cases are rising again and the Biden administration has begun a new vaccine campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Pentagon Official Charged With Running a Dogfighting Ring
description: Twelve dogs and an electrical plug with jumper cables were seized last month from the Maryland homes of two men charged with promoting a dogfighting ring.
content: A Department of Defense communications official has been charged with running a dogfighting ring that operated for many years and in which thousands of dollars were bet on violent matches, federal prosecutors in Maryland said this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay
title: A Mayor Goes AWOL in the Storm
description: With residents unprepared for New York City’s recent flooding, it was a day of unnecessary chaos and frustration.
content: On Friday, a flash flood washed over New York City, grinding the nation’s largest city to a halt and catching millions of people unaware.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Truss and Other Rivals Haunt Rishi Sunak at U.K. Conservatives’ Annual Conference
description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak hopes his governing party’s annual conference can revive his ailing poll numbers. Predecessors and would-be successors have other priorities.
content: Perhaps it’s inevitable for a political party that has held power in Britain for nearly 14 years, but the Conservative Party’s annual conference is rattling with the restless ghosts of its past and future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Drug Makers Agree to Negotiate With Medicare on Prices of 10 Medications
description: The pharmaceutical companies said they would begin talks even as several of them were suing the Biden administration over a new law authorizing the negotiations.
content: The manufacturers of 10 expensive medications have agreed to negotiate with the federal government for lower prices for Medicare recipients, the Biden administration announced on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Donald Trump’s fraud trial.
content: Donald Trump yesterday began his first of many trials — a civil fraud case that imperils his company and threatens his image. The New York State attorney general’s office accused the former president of inflating his riches by more than $2 billion to obtain favorable deals with banks and bragging rights about his wealth.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Texas Bishop Accuses Pope and the Vatican of Undermining Faith
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, October 3, 2023.
content: “I don’t necessarily want to volunteer to lose my head, but I’d honestly rather lose my head than lose my faith.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Guerrero
title: Jay-Z: Brooklyn Public Library Exhibit Is ‘More Than What I Deserved’
description: Senator Chuck Schumer, Mayor Eric Adams and other local dignitaries attended the library’s gala on Monday, which honored Jay-Z and his mother, Gloria Carter.
content: On Monday night, at the main branch of the Brooklyn Public Library, adults in tieless suits and flowing dresses populated the Youth Wing, sitting near stacks of children’s books, some on children’s chairs, with drinks in hand for the library’s 24th annual gala.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: 5 Ways to Get Insulin Resistance in Check
description: Insulin resistance can lead to a host of health problems — but it’s also reversible if you act. Here’s how.
content: Studies have confirmed it over and over again: Well over a third of adults in the United States are walking around with insulin resistance, a condition in which the body does not respond effectively to insulin and is unable to properly use glucose from the blood for energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: Gaetz Moves to Oust McCarthy, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — it’s available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Andres Kudacki
title: Digging for Secrets From the Raccoon in Your Garbage
description: Scientists are studying urban animals and the diseases they carry, to understand the potential risks to people, pets and the animals themselves.
content: Early one morning last month, Laura Dudley Plimpton found herself in Forest Park, in Queens, staring at a pair of captured raccoons. It was not the first time that Ms. Plimpton, an ecologist at Columbia University, had caught two of them in a cage trap designed for one. But typically when that happened, she would find a mother and a small kit inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Knvul Sheikh
title: What Is Insulin Resistance and How Do You Know if You Have It?
description: We asked experts to explain the condition, its early signs and when to take them seriously.
content: If you’ve spent time online recently, you’ve likely heard of insulin resistance. People using injectable drugs like Ozempic talk about it. Fitness enthusiasts suggest exercise routines to reverse it. Influencers market supplements that supposedly counter it. But what exactly is insulin resistance and how do you know if you have it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: ‘Wedgie’ on Disney Water Slide Caused Severe Injuries, Lawsuit Says
description: Emma McGuinness suffered “permanent bodily injury” on a visit to Disney World in Florida in 2019, according to a lawsuit that accuses Walt Disney Parks and Resorts of negligence.
content: Emma McGuinness traveled with her family to Walt Disney World in October 2019, in part to celebrate her 30th birthday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño and Mitch Smith
title: Young People Left in Limbo as Battle Over Transgender Care Shifts to Court
description: After losing in statehouses, supporters of transgender rights filed lawsuits in at least 14 states to convince judges that transition care for minors was safe.
content: When the summer started, transgender-rights supporters were riding a courtroom winning streak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Harvey Dickson
title: I Started Playing My Sax Outdoors. Then the Fans Came.
description: When your rehearsal space is the bank of the Hudson, the audience is a bit unconventional.
content: It was Year 2 of the pandemic, in the spring, that I hit on the idea of having my high school saxophone refurbished. My 48-year-old horn came back from the repair shop in Midtown Manhattan a week later. I put it together in my Upper West Side apartment and … for the love of God, it was loud. A couple of days later, I saw my downstairs neighbor in the lobby, and he asked, “Is that a sax I hear?” He professed to be OK with my rudimentary jazz stylings, but I was uncomfortable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman, Charlie Savage and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: Trump Wanted to Fire Missiles at Mexico. Now the G.O.P. Wants to Send Troops.
description: The Republican push to use military force in Mexico against drug cartels started in the Trump White House. He has plans to make the idea a reality in 2025.
content: The first time Donald Trump talked privately about shooting missiles into Mexico to take out drug labs, as far as his former aides can recall, was in early 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: A Rural Michigan Town Is the Latest Battleground in the U.S.-China Fight
description: Firestorms over Chinese investments, like a battery factory in Green Charter Township, are erupting as officials weigh the risks of taking money from an adversary.
content: Yard signs along the quiet country roads of Green Charter Township, Mich., home to horse farms and a 19th-century fish hatchery, blare a message that an angered community hopes is heard by local leaders, the Biden administration and China: “No Gotion.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: curt
description: This word has appeared in 53 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word curt has appeared in 53 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 19 in “Brooke Shields Dishes Trump and Madonna in a New Cabaret Show” by Jacob Bernstein:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: MAGA Wouldn’t Be Such a Threat if the Electoral System Worked
description: Americans should start to think — out loud — about the kinds of structural reforms we might pursue to make our democracy more resilient.
content: Last week, President Biden gave a wide-ranging interview to John Harwood of ProPublica that touched on his presidency, the Republican Party and the present state and future status of American democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: David French Interviews Stephanie Slade
description: The Oct. 3, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest-hosted by David French, with Stephanie Slade. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor and Michael C. Bender
title: Kari Lake Files to Run for Kyrsten Sinema’s Senate Seat in Arizona
description: Ms. Sinema left the Democratic Party last year to become an independent, but has not confirmed whether she will run for re-election.
content: Kari Lake, the Republican former news anchor who refused to acknowledge her loss in the Arizona governor’s race last year, filed paperwork on Tuesday to run for Senate, setting up what is expected to be one of the most competitive Senate races in the country as Republicans try to win back the chamber.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘To the Skinny Girl with Sad Eyes’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: To the skinny girl with sad eyes wearing a peacoat in the summer in New York City: You reminded me of my college days, when I was broken, living in my head, watching other students sing on the subway while I pinched my thighs. I bet you didn’t see me smile at you. I wouldn’t have noticed me either, back then. But I hope one day you too can take off that coat and slip into your heart, healed, thankful to your body, holding your daughters’ hands and humming songs with them as you skip to the train. — Katya Lidsky
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Kevin McCarthy Was Ousted as House Speaker
description: Also, Sam Bankman-Fried’s trial begins. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: Members of the House of Representatives voted this afternoon to remove Speaker Kevin McCarthy from his leadership position. The extraordinary move, which has never before happened, leaves the chamber without a leader and plunges it into dysfunctional chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola and Katrina Miller
title: Nobel Prize in Physics Awarded to 3 Scientists for Illuminating How Electrons Move
description: Techniques resulting from the work of Pierre Agostini, Ferenc Krausz and Anne L’Huillier let scientists capture the motions of subatomic particles moving at impossible speeds.
content: The Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded to Pierre Agostini, Ferenc Krausz and Anne L’Huillier on Tuesday for techniques that illuminate the subatomic realm of electrons, providing a new perspective into a previously unexplored domain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: They Were Given IUDs as Children Without Their Consent. Now, They Want Compensation.
description: A group of Indigenous women in Greenland say Danish doctors inserted intrauterine devices without their consent. They are now seeking damages from the Danish government.
content: Dozens of Indigenous women and girls from Greenland have said that they had intrauterine devices inserted without their consent in the 1960s and 1970s and have filed a complaint with the Danish government, demanding compensation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Li Yuan
title: China Is Suffering a Brain Drain. The U.S. Isn’t Exploiting It.
description: China’s brightest minds, including tech professionals, are emigrating, but many are not heading to America. We spoke to them to ask why.
content: They went to the best universities in China and in the West. They lived middle-class lives in Beijing, Shanghai and Shenzhen and worked for technology companies at the center of China’s tech rivalry with the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fred A. Bernstein
title: Harriet Pattison, 94, Dies; Landscape Architect With a Tie to Louis Kahn
description: After having a son with the famous architect, she built a career, often collaborating with Mr. Kahn on projects, including a New York memorial to Franklin D. Roosevelt.
content: Harriet Pattison, a noted landscape architect whose projects included the grounds of the Kimbell Art Museum in Fort Worth and the memorial to Franklin D. Roosevelt on Roosevelt Island in New York City, both of them collaborations with the architect Louis Kahn, with whom she had a son, died on Monday at her home in Newtown Square, Pa. She was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Brantley
title: How Patrick Stewart Made the Jump to Warp Speed
description: In his fond memoir “Making It So,” the actor traces the path from the working class to the Shakespearean stage to “Star Trek” superstardom.
content: A ruddy blush of modesty colors “Making It So,” Patrick Stewart’s engaging self-portrait of life on the British stage and the starship U.S.S. Enterprise. Humility is not, of course, the trait that first comes to mind with big-name actors, for whom a strapping ego would seem to be a job requirement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Dibdin
title: 6 Podcasts for the Spooky Season
description: These shows deliver disturbing true stories of everyday horror, lively recaps of scary movies and creepy scripted dramas about the supernatural.
content: There’s an adage about horror movies, often attributed to Alfred Hitchcock: What you don’t see is more frightening than what you do. This makes audio dramas excellent vehicles for the horror genre, because the absence of visual storytelling forces listeners to fill in the gaps. Whatever the mind conjures up, custom-made for unique neuroses and fears, may well be scarier than any tangible monster or ghoul.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Little Troublemaker
description: Troy Laedtke makes his New York Times debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Rod Wave Tops Olivia Rodrigo in Tight Race on Album Chart
description: The rapper and singer’s latest LP, “Nostalgia,” beat Rodrigo’s “Guts” to No. 1 by the equivalent of about 500 sales.
content: Last week, the rapper and singer Rod Wave edged Olivia Rodrigo from the No. 1 spot on Billboard’s album chart by just a few thousand sales. This week he has done it again, but the margin was narrowed to a few hundred.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Zia ur-Rehman
title: With Surge in Attacks, Militants Begin New Era of Bloodshed in Pakistan
description: For nearly a decade, the country had seemingly broken the cycle of violence, but extremist groups have bounced back since the Taliban regained control in neighboring Afghanistan.
content: It was a bloody reminder that the dark days of extremist violence appeared to have returned to Pakistan: a suicide attack on a religious festival in the country’s southwest this past week that left around 60 people dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Senate Delegation to Travel to China During Congressional Recess
description: The trip comes at a time of heightened tensions between Beijing and Washington, as the Biden administration restricts investments in key Chinese sectors while trying to improve relations.
content: Senator Chuck Schumer, the majority leader, is expected to lead a bipartisan delegation of six senators on a trip to China next week, the latest in a series of high-level visits by U.S. officials to Beijing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Trump Targets Nikki Haley as She Climbs in the Polls
description: Ms. Haley, a former South Carolina governor, has taken the attacks as a signal that the Republican front-runner sees her as a threat.
content: Until recently, former President Donald J. Trump mostly ignored Nikki Haley, a former governor of South Carolina and his onetime United Nations ambassador turned rival in the 2024 presidential race. No longer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nili Blanck
title: Mediano o Grande? An Ice Cream Tour of Mexico City
description: A guide to five of the capital’s best ice cream parlors, from artisanal storefronts with flavors like prickly pear and blue maize to classic shops where generations have gone for treats.
content: Mexico does not have a long history with ice cream. The country’s first versions of the dessert were akin to snow cones, made from ice that was harvested from the summits of the country’s volcanoes and transported via donkeys and mules to urban areas. With a dash of salt and fruit mixed in, these “raspados” (literally, shavings) or “nieves” (snow), were prepared in flavors like lime and guava and were sold out of pushcarts along streets, just as they are today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Ekaterina Bodyagina
title: Small-Town Revolt Reveals Larger German Concerns About Arming Ukraine
description: The resistance of tiny Grossenhain to a new arms plant shows how the government’s plan for a more assertive foreign policy is struggling to gain traction.
content: When government leaders in Saxony learned that Rheinmetall, Germany’s most prominent arms manufacturer, was considering building a new munitions factory in the former East German state, they saw visions of economic boom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Sweeney
title: How Many Face Products Do I Really Need?
description: Sifting through all the advice can be confusing. But dermatologists say simpler is better.
content: Q: I’m confused about how to take care of the skin on my face. What are the basics?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Nicholas Nehamas and Alyce McFadden
title: Trump Said Shoplifters Should Be Shot, Part of a String of Violent Remarks
description: Recent incendiary statements by the former president come at a time when his supporters are already angry over his indictments.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump had a lot to say on the first day of the fraud trial against him and his company. Speaking to reporters at a Manhattan courthouse on Monday, he dismissed the judge as a “rogue” justice and said he did not “think the people of this country are going to stand for it.” And he focused on the official who filed the lawsuit against him, New York’s attorney general, Letitia James.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Gov. J.B. Pritzker’s Letter to President Biden
description: The Illinois governor called for the president, a fellow Democrat, to step up federal aid as Chicago struggles to house thousands of migrants.
content: The Illinois governor called for the president, a fellow Democrat, to step up federal aid as Chicago struggles to house thousands of migrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by Katherine Schulten
title: Student News Quiz | Trials, Taylor Swift, Nobel Prizes
description: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
content: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William B. Davis, Madison Dong, John Keefe, Judson Jones and Bea Malsky
title: Tracking Tropical Storm Lidia
description: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Lidia.
content: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Lidia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Cook Escobar, Kennedy Elliott, Zach Levitt, John-Michael Murphy, Alicia Parlapiano, Scott Reinhard, Rachel Shorey, Ashley Wu and Karen Yourish
title: Vote Count: House Removes McCarthy as Speaker
description: Here’s how each member of the House voted on the successful motion to remove Kevin McCarthy as speaker.
content: Here’s how each member of the House voted on the successful motion to remove Kevin McCarthy as speaker.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Best Deals From Target Circle Week 2023
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Greenwich Village Apartment That Was Meant to Be
description: After the deal fell through, they couldn’t stop thinking about the apartment and those Manhattan views. Sometimes persistence pays off.
content: After the deal fell through, they couldn’t stop thinking about the apartment and those Manhattan views. Sometimes persistence pays off.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 104-Year-Old Breaks World Record for Oldest Skydiver
description: “She did a lot better than most people,” said the skydiving instructor who jumped with Dorothy Hoffner at Skydive Chicago.
content: “She did a lot better than most people,” said the skydiving instructor who jumped with Dorothy Hoffner at Skydive Chicago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justine Martin
title: Oasis
description: At the dawn of their teenage years, the bond between the twins Raphaël and Rémi begins to weaken. But during the summer, time seems to stand still.
content: At the dawn of their teenage years, the bond between the twins Raphaël and Rémi begins to weaken. But during the summer, time seems to stand still.
source.name: The New York Times
